content.description:
The easiest route to the top of the tower that follows an easy and short corner and crack system. The crux is pulling into the small chimney at the top and not pulling off any holds. 

Once you find the tower look for the obvious crack and corner system up the shortest (east) side of the tower and follow this to the summit and rappel tat slung around a boulder.
Cams BD #.4-2 are more than enough and extra rappel cord just in case

climbs.name: Chopping Block
climbs.fa: Justin Krawetz and Liam Arbuckle, Oct 2018

content.description:
The route follows ledges on the cliff directly opposite of the tower. Follow step looking features up to the right of the wall and take care to not pull them off. Finish by following the crack to the top of the cliff face. 

From the bottom of the east side of the tower, turn around and find the blocky looking crack and flake system on the wall connected to the mountain. 
SR or slings to make and anchor for a TR

climbs.name: Entrapment
climbs.fa: Justin Krawetz and Liam Arbuckle, Oct 2018

content.description:
Climb the curving hand crack and surmount some loose blocks then continue through the crux top mini chimney and either squeeze (emphasis on squeeze) your way through if you're small enough or use some face holds to help inch your way up through the outside of the chimney. 

Once on top of the cliffs looking towards the tower, scramble down to the base of these cliffs and find a curving crack with a small chimney at the top.
SR, setting up a TR here requires some gear and slung boulders

From the approach from the road, go around to the north side of the tower and find a wide overhanging crack on the north face. Start up the offwidth crack and jam or layback the overhanging crack until it turns into a nice hand or thin hands crack. Continue jamming or laybacking up the pumpy face to a good stemming rest before coming over the initial lip of the climb (be careful of swinging away from the wall here if on TR as it is very overhung). From here follow the finger cracks and face to the large tree sitting on the ledge above.

Scramble around to the north side of the tower and find the gapping crack in the face, this is the start of the climb.
If leading, BD #.3-4 with optional #5 and/or a #6 for the start (if you don't like offwidths). Large cordelette and two #2 and one #3 camalot to set up a TR

Move up the splitter slanting and overhanging hand crack and use the walls when necessary for friction (or purely jam the crack) since there aren't many footholds. Pull through the cruxy roof feature a little ways off the ground and enjoy the rest of the excellent jams. You can start at the very bottom of the crack for maximum fun, or start on a ledge a little ways off the ground.

From scrambling down to the base of the cliffs opposing the tower, look for a slanting hand crack directly after crossing the log bridge. 
SR with an extra BD #2 and #3 for comfort. Long slings if setting up a TR.

Secluded approximately 40m tower and surrounding walls that hold many granite cracks and faces. Rock quality ranges from excellent on the step and overhung sections to mossy and chossy on lower angle areas.
